chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text:
We will calculate the net present value (NPV). Knowing that the method of estimation of the present value of future cash flows using the discounting technique, and deducting the capital investment from the discounted amount is known as the net present value method It is measured by the following formula:

$$\tag{1}\text{NPV}=X-Y$$

Where $X$ represents the present value of an investment's net cash inflows, and $Y$ represents the initial cost of investment.

Let's compute the present value of an investment's net cash inflows $(X)$ using the $11\%$ rate:

$$\begin{aligned}

X&=\frac{\$15,000}{1.11}+\frac{\$17,000}{(1.11)^2}+\frac{\$13,000}{(1.11)^3}\\
&=\$13,513.51351+\$13,797.58137+\$9,505.487957\\
&=\$36,816.58284

\end{aligned}$$

Now we can calculate the NPV, by plugging the value into the formula $1$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=\$36,816.58284-\$34,000\\
&=\$2,816.58284

\end{aligned}$$

The NPV is positive at $11\%$ return. Hence, it is a good project, therefore, the company should accept the project.

Let's compute the present value of an investment's net cash inflows $(X)$ using the $24\%$ rate:

$$\begin{aligned}

X&=\frac{\$15,000}{1.24}+\frac{\$17,000}{(1.24)^2}+\frac{\$13,000}{(1.24)^3}\\
&=\$12,096.77419+\$11,056.19147+\$6,818.334396\\
&=\$29,971.30006

\end{aligned}$$

Now we can calculate the NPV, by plugging the value into the formula $1$:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=\$29,971.30006-\$34,000\\
&=-\$4,028.69994

\end{aligned}$$

The NPV is negative at $24\%$ return. Hence, it is not a profitable project,  therefore, the company should reject the project.
